text: Rory 10 from Edinburgh asks why do you
want to get more power in Westminister
if you want an independent Scotland I
campaigned in the referendum for
Scotland to be an independent country I
wanted people to vote yes but we didn't
vote yes and that means Scotland is
still part of the Westminster system so
the decisions that are taking at
Westminster will affect people across
Scotland so it really matters that the
decisions that are taken at Westminster
are good decisions and I think having
lots of SNP MPs in the House of Commons
will mean that the decisions that are
taken there are better decisions there
was a vote on independence in September
the majority of Scottish people
votives know why do you want another
vote on independence well I'm not
planning another vote just know we've
just had a referendum and it was I in my
view it was a great experience for the
country if this Westminster elections
not about independence if you've all SNP
on me the 70 or not voting for Scotland
to become independent you're voting for
Scotland to have a much louder voice at
Westminster Matthew aged 11 from Salford
ask if you can't wait and be Prime
Minister who do you think should be I
don't want David Cameron to be Prime
Minister because I don't think Tory
governments have ever been good for
Scotland and but if Ed Miliband is to be
Prime Minister I want him to be a play
minister that delivers new change and
doesn't just end up doing the same kind
of things that David Cameron would have
done so
the SNP would be there hopefully to make
ed Miliband a wee bit braver this is my
question I've seen interviews with
politicians why do they always kind of
dodge questions or at least try to
believe it or not even although I'm a
politician and I'm sure I've you know
people have watched me on television
from time to time and so I was dodging
questions but when I watch politicians
do I get really frustrated as well so I
try very hard no
to dodge questions and to answer
questions as a straight forwardly as I
can I'm sure I don't always manage it
that's for you guys to judge her welcome
to it why has it taken so long for a
woman to be First Minister what are the
challenges facing more women in politics
the Scottish Parliament only existed for
15 years and those are women First
Minister so I suppose we should maybe
actually take up a bit afraid in the
fact that it hasn't actually taken that
long in Scotland you know women get as
much talked about and written about how
they look what they wear what the hair
looks like then they do about what they
see and yeah that's can I off putting to
younger women so these are all things
we've got to change I think we're making
progress but there's still a long way to
go
Madison age 10 from Cambridge asks if
you could do anything change change the
UK what would it be and why
if I could do one thing above all else
it would be to give every single young
person living in this country an equal
chance to get on and succeed and make
the most of their own light regardless
of whether they're a boy a ghetto
regardless of whether their mums and
dads are rich or or otherwise
listen to Thomas and James Macy
